message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus would present with a narrowing of the lumen of the intestine and a twist in the intestine. Hirschsprung disease would present with an absence of peristalsis and the absence of ganglion cells in the terminal colon. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis would present with projectile vomiting and olive-shaped mass palpated on the right abdomen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest an obstruction in the upper gastrointestinal tract, and the most likely cause is jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus can also present with bilious vomiting, but it typically occurs earlier in life. Hirschsprung disease and hypertrophic pyloric stenosis cause gastrointestinal obstruction in different parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bilious vomiting, distended upper abdomen, hypoactive bowel sounds, and x-ray findings all point towards the diagnosis of jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus may also present with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension, but typically has more pronounced symptoms and findings. Hirschsprung disease presents with delayed passage of meconium and constipation. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting and a palpable olive-like mass in the epigastrium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn’s symptoms suggest an obstruction in the upper gastrointestinal tract, which is consistent with jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus would cause more severe symptoms and a "double-bubble" sign on x-ray. Hirschsprung disease would present with constipation and not bilious vomiting. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis would present with non-bilious vomiting and a palpable "olive" on physical examination. The mother's history of smoking and cocaine use may be contributing factors to the development of the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with bilious vomiting, a distended upper abdomen, hypoactive bowel sounds, and an x-ray showing 3 gas shadows in the upper abdomen with a gasless distal abdomen, all of which suggest jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus may cause similar symptoms, but the x-ray findings would be different. Hirschsprung disease would present with delayed passage of meconium in the neonatal period. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis would present with nonbilious vomiting and a palpable "olive" in the epigastric region.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the x-ray findings suggest jejunal atresia, as there are three gas shadows in the upper abdomen and a gasless distal abdomen. Malrotation with volvulus may also present with bilious vomiting, but the x-ray findings would be different. Hirschsprung disease and hypertrophic pyloric stenosis do not typically present with bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings indicate that the newborn has jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus would show a "whirlpool sign" on imaging. Hirschsprung disease would cause constipation and gas accumulation in the rectum, and hypertrophic pyloric stenosis would cause projectile vomiting with a palpable olive-shaped mass in the abdomen. The mother's history of smoking and cocaine use is not directly related to the newborn's condition but may have other implications for the baby's long-term health.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious vomiting, distended upper abdomen, hypoactive bowel sounds, and x-ray showing gas shadows in the upper abdomen with a gasless distal abdomen are all characteristic of jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus would present as sudden onset of bilious vomiting associated with a stable distended abdomen, whereas Hirschsprung disease would present with delayed passage of meconium and progressive constipation. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis would present with projectile vomiting in the first few weeks of life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting, distended upper abdomen, hypoactive bowel sounds, and x-ray showing gas shadows in upper abdomen with gasless distal abdomen are consistent with jejunal atresia. Malrotation with volvulus will present with upper abdominal distention, vomiting and bloody stool. Hirschsprung disease will present with failure to pass meconium and may have distended abdomen but not bilious vomiting. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis may present with vomiting, but it will not have a distended upper abdomen or gas shadows on x-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a bowel obstruction, and the x-ray shows gas shadows in the upper abdomen with a gasless distal abdomen, indicating a high grade or complete obstruction. Among the options, only Jejunal atresia fits the presentation, with bilious vomiting, distended upper abdomen, and hypoactive bowel sounds. Malrotation with volvulus can also cause bilious vomiting, but it usually presents in the first week of life. Hirschsprung disease typically presents with delayed passage of meconium and constipation from birth, while Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis usually presents after the first week of life with non-bilious projectile vomiting.
